About

Hello! My name is Rachel and I'm a senior studying Media Studies and Computer Science at UC Berkeley. I'm a user experience designer and developer who applies human-centered design to build products that will delight users. I seek to blur the lines between engineering, art, and humanities.

If you're interested in working with me on web applications and UX design projects or if you'd like to chat, feel free to connect with me using the form below. I look forward to hearing from you!

TrashScan

TrashScan is an interactive device that uses object-recognition and machine learning to sort waste into the correct bins while educating students about sustainability! For our final project for Critical Practices, we interviewed staff at Cal Recycling, a part of the greater sustainability community on the UC Berkeley campus, to design a solution for the problems of cross-contamination in bins and students' apathy toward learning to throw away trash correctly. Learn more about the process of designing the final prototype on our Hackster page. It has been featured as a Project Spotlight at the Jacobs Institute of Design at UC Berkeley.

  • Raspberry Pi, CamFind API, Processing
  • November 2015 - December 2015
  • NWMEDIA 190 / CS 294
  • Raspberry Pi, Sustainability

ThredUP Personal Shops Remake

I spent my summer as a Product Manager Intern at thredUP building a new and improved version of Personal Shops, a personalization tool that will enable users to quickly find relevant items to purchase based on the searches they save (whether they are free searches or filters). thredUP is an online fashion resale shop (available for web and on Android and iOS). First, I dug through our data to identify trends for our saved searches. For user research, I conducted a survey and followed up with phone interviews to identify users' shopping behaviors patterns and main objectives for using Personal Shops. After compiling user research, I used a mental model that would guide our design decisions, the KPIs set, and the rest of the product cycle to achieve goals according to the user's thought process. We tested internally and invited users for user testing sessions to test our first iteration of the prototype. Taking their feedback, I iterated for a second version and established milestones for completing the product features. View the prototype of the second iteration here. Only the last three elements in Recently Searched are active in the prototype. A more detailed Behance project describing my process is in the works!

  • Sketch, FramerJS
  • June - August 2015
  • thredUP
  • Product Management, Prototyping, User Research, User Experience

ThredUP Design Wiki

I set up the web framework for designers and engineers to easily access thredUP's brand guidelines. The Product team noticed that at times there weren't clear understandings between designers and engineers of what the brand guidelines were. Since the brand guidelines for iOS, Android, and web still have yet to be finalized in the midst of the Shop Overhaul process, the content isn't filled for most of the pages.

  • Jekyll, Bootstrap, HTML/CSS, JavaScript
  • July - August 2015
  • thredUP
  • Web Development

Virtual Reality Museum

For our semester-long project with Berkeley Innovation, my group members and I worked with Immersio to design a new user experience for its virtual art gallery. After interviewing art gallery owners and conducting user research about purchasing and observing art in a virtual experience, we concluded that viewing art in a virtual reality space should be done in a museum as a supplement for educating museum visitors and archiving past exhibits to introduce virtual reality to the masses. To make the museum visitors experience as immersive as possible and give the user more control of the space, we had panels of different exhibits surrounding the user (in the center of the circle of panels) as they were standing in a museum lobby. View our Behance for more details.

  • Unity, Photoshop
  • February - May 2015
  • Immersio
  • Virtual Reality

Pixel Plots

Group final project for the Rails Decal. Users can create their own unique grid designs by clicking on the pixel to either fill in it or remove the color. Users can upvote or downvote other users' plots.

  • Ruby on Rails, Bootstrap
  • December 2014
  • Rails Decal
  • Web Application

Fashion and Student Trends

I coded and designed the Wordpress layout for Fashion and Student Trends, the premier fashion student organization at UC Berkeley. It is both a blog with the latest fashion stories and an informational website about the student organization. It also includes photoshoot lookbooks.

  • HTML, CSS, Wordpress
  • September 2014 - Present
  • Fashion and Student Trends
  • Web Development

Modern Citizen Blog

Modern Citizen is the online style destination for the modern woman. The problem I sought to address as a web development intern was creating features and pages for content creation and creative brand content. My mental model throughout the design process was "how can I make customers clearly understand our brand vision and engage with what it means to be a modern woman?" I coded Modern Citizen's blog layout and other website features for engagement with social media.

  • HTML, CSS, JavaScript
  • June-August 2014
  • Modern Citizen
  • Web Development
